posts.title: AI → YouTube Clip Machine (how it really works)
posts.lede: Short-form clipping is one of the most repeatable AI workflows right now — but only if you pick a format you can produce forever.
posts.whatsHappening: People take long videos (podcasts, lectures, streams), identify the best moments, add captions, and publish consistently. AI handles the boring parts; the human handles taste and selection.
steps: Choose a single source format (podcast, lecture, streams) and one niche.
Batch process: pull 30–60 minutes of footage per session.
Use AI to find highlights, then manually pick the top 5 moments.
Caption + add a consistent visual style so it feels like a series.
Post on a schedule and link to one offer (affiliate/tool/newsletter).
posts.time: 2–4 hours to set up, then ~60 minutes per batch day.
posts.skill: Beginner to intermediate (editing helps, but templates carry you).
posts.truth: The money comes from consistency + distribution, not the clip tool.

posts.title: Vibe-coded Micro‑SaaS: tiny app, tiny price, real money
posts.lede: Micro‑SaaS works when you solve a single annoying problem for a single type of person — then charge a price that feels like nothing.
posts.whatsHappening: People are shipping small web apps in days, not months. AI accelerates the coding, but the winning move is picking a clear niche and keeping the feature list tiny.
steps: Write the problem in one sentence (no commas).
Build the smallest version that works end-to-end.
Add payment after it works (Stripe or LemonSqueezy).
Launch somewhere specific (Reddit niche, community, YouTube demo).
Improve based on real user pain — not your imagination.
posts.time: A weekend for v1 if scope stays tiny.
posts.skill: Beginner-friendly if you follow patterns; stronger if you can debug.
posts.truth: The hard part is restraint: don’t build a platform, build a tool.

posts.title: Prompt Product: sell a template people actually use
posts.lede: Prompt products sell when they reduce anxiety and save time — not because the prompt is “clever.”
posts.whatsHappening: Instead of selling prompts as magic spells, people bundle a prompt + example outputs + a simple workflow. Buyers pay for clarity and speed.
steps: Pick one audience with one recurring pain (teachers, job seekers, creators).
Create a one-page workflow and 3 example outputs.
Package it as a template (Notion/Doc/Canva) plus a short guide.
Sell it with a simple demo page and a couple of screenshots.
Iterate based on questions buyers ask — those become v2 features.
posts.time: 2–3 hours to build a solid first version.
posts.skill: Beginner (writing + packaging matters more than tech).
posts.truth: People pay for a system they can reuse, not a single prompt.
